content_scrubbed:
False equivalency. The fact that historically women-only colleges are a prestigious choice for many smart women is a better determining factor. 

Also since when is being in congress a marker of success? Most of them are just rich (senators) or professional politicians, which privileged liberal_arts college grads can afford to enter in to. 

Thanks for the "facts" from an opinion piece by the way. And the Forbes link to the "30%" on the Businessweek list of "rising women in corporate America" (whatever that means) is to a women[.] college booster site, not Businessweek. 

A group of people trying to maintain a status quo that benefits them being biased. Well paint me green and call me broccoli. 

Also this from the article you cherry picked bad stats from:

Physical and social separation from men is not the goal of a women[.] college; today almost all are in consortiums or close proximity to co-ed colleges.

[Also this:](http://www. forbes. com/sites/ccap/2012/02/16/the-male-female-ratio-in-college/#755f1b415250)

On a national scale, public universities had the most even division between male and female students, with a male-female ratio of 43. 6–56. 4. While that difference is substantial, it still is smaller than private not-for-profit institutions (42. 5-57. 5) or all private schools (40. 7-59. 3).

One might ask: "But maybe there are just more women in the USA?" From the same article:

 It should also be noted that the national male-female ratio for 18-24 year olds is actually 51-49, meaning there are more (traditionally) college-aged males than females.

So should we get some male only colleges going?! Nope. Creating artificial environments is sticking to old vestiges of sexist stereotypes.
